xhtml:div.xhtml:p: This provisional document is derived from research conducted utilizing the Oracle 10g program, the Oracle’s Technology Network (otn.oracle.com), various published books and the Oracle 9i Database baseline document. The provisional status is based on the lack of sufficient informational resources for this newly released application. This document provides the necessary settings and procedures for the secure installation, setup, configuration, and operation of an Oracle 10g database environment. Targeted for newly established and/or deployed Oracle 10g database in Unix or Windows operating system platforms, it is for the use of DOE advanced Oracle Database Administrators. With the use of the settings and procedures in this document, an Oracle database may be secured from conventional “out of the box” threats. Recognizing the nature of security cannot and should not be limited to only the application, the scope of this document is not limited to only Oracle specific settings or configurations, but also addresses backups, archive logs, “best practices” processes and procedures that are applicable to general software and hardware security.

New to the 10g baseline document is organization into chapters based on logical groupings. Within chapters, items are organized by level. All items function on layer 7, the Application layer of the OSI model, or, as in the case of many policy items, are not applicable to the OSI model. Therefore, groupings via the OSI model would not be relevant.

Applicable items were verified and tested against an Oracle 10g default install on both a default Windows 2000 Server and a Solaris 9 Unix machine. The Oracle version used was 10.0.1.2 install disks, patched up to 10.0.1.3. Where the default setting is less secure then the recommended setting a caution has been provided in the comment section below the separator bar or as a note below a chapter heading. Default installs for both the operating system and the database may differ dependent on versions and options installed so this is to be used as a general guide only. Unix settings should translate to other varieties of Unix, but were only tested against Solaris 9. If any differences are found, please contact the CIS team.

This document is not intended as a guidance document. It is the minimum required means of diligence for the protection of an Oracle 10g database. For issues of guidance, the NSA guideline web site (http://www.nsa.gov/snac) and the DOE guideline resources web site (http://www.cisecurity.org/bench_oracle.html) each provide excellent guidance documents for both operating systems and specific applications.

xhtml:div.xhtml:p: User communities implementing an Oracle 10g database that are required to meet the FIPS140-2 standard of encryption are facing a unique problem. To set the Oracle 10g software to the FIPS140 standard requires the SQLNET.FIPS_140 setting be set to TRUE and in turn the SQLNET.ENCRYPTION_TYPES_SERVER setting be set to DES|DES40. With the SQLNET_140 set to TRUE any setting other than DES|DES40 for the SQLNET.ENCRYPTION_TYPES_SERVER may cause an error, but the DES or DES40 standard for encryption are at best weak standards and are already subject to several known compromises. See notes 5.02 and 5.03.

Even as DES is an accepted standard for legacy systems under current FIPS140-2 standards, if FIPS140 compliance is mandated and a stronger encryption standard is required, then a third party encryption system must be used.
Third party encryption resources for Oracle include:
Relational Database Consultants;
Semantica Software;
NEC Tricryption
Ingrian Networks;

Each of these encryption providers products encrypt the databases at a file, row or field level without requiring the setting of the SQLNET.FIPS_140 value to TRUE or the setting of the SQLNET.ENCRYPTION_TYPES_SERVER to DES|DES140. They also offer encryption using 3DES, AES, and additional algorithms.

The goal for the waiver or exception to the baseline is not to exempt or negate security considerations, but rather provide a means for the maintenance of the security standards outside of the mandated means.

xhtml:div.xhtml:h3: Compensation for the waiver or exemption
xhtml:div.xhtml:p: The steps taken to compensate for the waiver or the exemption should equal or surpass the standard for security of the affected element. Further, the compensation must not be in conflict with or any way jeopardize existing security measures.

xhtml:div.xhtml:h3: Documentation of the waiver or exception
xhtml:div.xhtml:p: Because security methodologies are both contextual and interrelated, a waiver or exception cannot exist in isolation from the scope of other security methodologies and cannot be executed without at least the awareness and/or understanding of all other security agents functioning under the same security hierarchy. Toward insuring all other security agents are informed of the waiver or exception, detailed documentation of the waiver or exception should be made and circulated. At a minimum the documentation should include a detailed description of the justification/s, nature, scope, duration, and means of compensation for the waiver or exception.

By their nature, the justifications for waivers or exception cannot be predicted. Reasons might include situations where compliance with the standard would adversely affect the accomplishment of the mission of the computer system, or where compliance with the standard would cause a major financial impact on the operator, which is not offset by concurrent or subsequent cost of a security breach.

The nature of the waiver or exception delineates where within the hierarchy of software, hardware, physical, infrastructure, or personnel the exemption will be effected. If the deviation from the standards of the baseline is of a scope to cover multiple elements, then the effect on each element must be documented.
The scope of the waiver or exception provides the range to which operating system/s, application/s, machine/s, network/s, person/s or procedures will be covered by the exemption.

The compensation of the waiver or exception details what will be put in place as a substitute for the mandated settings, procedures or protocols. The explanation of the compensation must include how it will meet or exceed the existing standards for security.
The duration of the waiver or exception explains how long the exemption will be in effect.

In almost all cases, a waiver or exception should not be accepted as a static modification, but should be considered as an exemption of fixed duration that will be resolved by the restoration of the software, hardware, procedure, personnel, or other security element/s to the defined security standard.

xhtml:div.xhtml:h3: Steps at the expiration of the duration
xhtml:div.xhtml:p: At the expiration of the duration, the waiver or exception to should be reviewed for means to return the software, hardware, procedure, personnel, or other security element/s to the defined security standard. This is not a renewal process, but must include a re-examination of the justification, nature, scope, and duration of the waiver or exception.

xhtml:div.xhtml:h2: Appendix E - Using Enterprise Manager Grid Control for Patch Management and Policy Violations
xhtml:div.xhtml:p: The Oracle 10g Enterprise Manager Grid Control application has two functions directly related to securing Oracle and its host. If the Oracle Enterprise Manager Grid Control application is deployed, follow these recommendations. For more detailed information of this functionality please refer to the Oracle documentation, Oracle Enterprise Manager Concepts 10g Release 1 (10.1) Part No. B12016-02andOracle Enterprise Manager Advanced Configuration 10g Release 1 (10.1) Part No. B12013-03.

The Oracle 10g Enterprise Manager Grid Control application can be set up to automatically access Oracle MetaLink to search for and download any new patches Available for your Oracle install. The administrator can then schedule and apply the patch(es) to any host in the enterprise.

The Oracle 10g Enterprise Manager Grid Control application can show policy violations for any database or host in the enterprise. The violations can be fixed or ignored so they will not show up in future reports.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Ensures that Oracle will check that the name of a database link is the same as that of the remote database.
Default is FALSE.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This must be limited as much as possible. Typically SYS gets 20 roles by default.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Connection without a password must be prevented.
Default is FALSE.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: init.ora: remote_os_roles= FALSE

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Connection spoofing must be prevented.
Default is FALSE.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: init.ora: remote_listener="" (A null string)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Prevent the use of a listener on a remote machine separate from the database instance.
Default is "" (A null string) NOTE: the field should be left empty. A space is not a null string.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: init.ora: Audit_trail parameter set to OS, DB, or TRUE

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Audit_trail parameter set to OS, DB, or TRUE

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Ensures that basic audit features are used. Recommend setting audit_trail to OS as it reduces the likelihood of a Denial of Service attack and it is easier to secure the audit trail. OS is required if the auditor is distinct from the DBA. Any auditing information stored in the database is viewable and modifiable by the DBA. Even with the AUDIT_TRAIL value set to FALSE, an audit session will report, "Audit succeeded."
Default=NONE.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: init.ora: os_authent_prefix="" (A null string)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: It must be set to limit the external use of an account to an IDENTIFIED EXTERNALLY specified user.
Default is set to OPS$, which is for backward compatibility to previous versions. Null is recommended.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: init.ora: os_roles=FALSE

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: O/S roles are subject to control outside the database. The duties and responsibilities of DBAs and system administrators must be separated.
Default is FALSE.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: Test items encryption related items for transport to and from Oracle instances and managment of PKI

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS - General: Review requirement for integrity and confidentiality requirements.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Review requirement for integrity and confidentiality requirements.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Only implement OAS if a local integrity/encryption policy does not already exist, e.g., IPSec or other means for providing integrity/confidentiality services.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS – Encryption Type: SQLNET.ENCRYPTION_SERVER=REQUIRED

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This ensures that regardless of the settings on the user, if communication takes place it must be encrypted.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS – Encryption Type: SQLNET.ENCRYPTION_CLIENT=(ACCEPTED|REQUESTED|REQUIRED)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Communication is only possible on the basis of an agreement between the client and the server regarding the connection encryption. To ensure encrypted communciation, set the value to “REQUIRED.”
With the server set to “REQUIRED” the client must match the encryption for valid communcation to take place.
NOTE: failure to specify one of the values will result in an error when an attempt is made to connect to a FIPS 140-1 compliant server.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS – Encryption Seed: SQLNET.CRYPTO_SEED=some70charValue

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Where possible use the maximum seed value (70 characters). Please be aware that in 9i and early version of 10g, the CRYPTO_SEED does not take the following characters: single quote(‘), double quote(“), space, number sign(#), equal sign(=), right or left paranthesis (()), comma(,), or backslash(\).
Please see Metalink article 281928.1 for more information.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS – FIPS Compliance: SQLNET.FIPS_140=TRUE

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: For FIPS 140-1 compliance, the FIPS value must be set to “TRUE.” The default value for this setting is “FALSE.”
NOTE: This value is not settable using the Oracle Net Manager. To set this value you must use a text editor and modify the sqlnet.ora file.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS – Encryption Method (FIPS 140): SQLNET.ENCRYPTION_TYPES_SERVER=(DES|DES40)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: To satisfy the FIPS 140-1 criterion in Oracle, only DES or DES40 may be used and there must be an agreement between the SERVER and the CLIENT.
NOTE: These encryption standards do not meet the newer FIPS 140-2 standard.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS – Encryption Methods: In decending order of preference encryption keys for both client and server must be set to the maximum feasible value.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: In decending order of preference encryption keys for both client and server must be set to the maximum feasible value.
Available values with =>128 bit key encryption include:
3 Key Triple DES 168 bit effective key size - 3DES168
Available values with less than 128 bit key encryption include:
2 Key Triple DES 112 bit effective key size - 3DES112
1 Key DES 56 bit effective key size - DES
DES40 40 bit effective key size - DES40

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: At a minimum, use 128 bit key encryption.
Note: There are publicly Available attacks that allow a Pentium III to crack 40 and 56 bit key encryptions. Encryption below 128 bit keys should be considered minimally effective.

Unfortunately without the use of a third party encryption method, with the FIPS value set to TRUE, only DES and DES40 are allowed as legal values. This sets the database to the standard of FIPS140-1 and not to the standard of FIPS140-2.
For more information about FIPS 140-2 issues, please see Appendix C.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS – Integrity Protection: Integrity check for communication between the server and the client must be established.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Integrity check for communication between the server and the client must be established.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The integrity check for communication can prevent data modifications. Two check sum algorithms are Available; SHA-1 and MD5.
Oracle's implementation of this setting also offers protection against replay attacks.
Reference Oracle Metalink 76637 for more information.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS – Integrity Protection: Set SQLNET.CRYPTO_CHECKSUM_TYPES_SERVER=(SHA1)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If possible, use SHA1 instead of MD5.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS – Oracle Wallet Owner Permissions: Set configuration method for Oracle Wallet. Ensure only the appropriate Oracle user account has access to the wallet.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Set configuration method for Oracle Wallet. Ensure only the appropriate Oracle user account has access to the wallet.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The Oracle service account must have access to the wallet.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS – Oracle Wallet Trusted Certificates: Remove certificate authorities (CAs) that are not required.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Remove certificate authorities (CAs) that are not required.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Trust only those CAs that are required by clients and servers.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS – Oracle Wallet Trusted Certificates Import: When adding CAs, verify fingerprint of CA certificates.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: When adding CAs, verify fingerprint of CA certificates.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: When adding CA certificates via out-of-band methods, use fingerprints to verify the certificate.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS – Certificate Request Key Size: Request the maximum key size available.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Request the maximum key size available.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Select the largest key size available that is compatible with the network environment.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS – Server Oracle Wallet Auto Login: Allow Auto Login for the server's Oracle Wallet

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Allow Auto Login for the server's Oracle Wallet

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: For Windows Oracle database servers, SSL will not work unless Auto Login is set.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS – SSL Tab: SSL is preferred method. If PKI not possible, use OAS Integrity/Encryption.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: SSL is preferred method. If PKI not possible, use OAS Integrity/Encryption.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: OAS Integrity/Encryption should only be used if required because of non-SSL clients.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS – SSL Version: Set SSL version. SSL_VERSION = 3.0

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Do not set this parameter with “Any”.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS – SSL Cipher Suite: Set SSL Cipher Suite. SSL_CIPHER_SUITES = SSL_RSA_WITH_3DES_EDE_CBC_SHA)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Set SSL Cipher Suite. SSL_CIPHER_SUITES = SSL_RSA_WITH_3DES_EDE_CBC_SHA)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: At a minimum, triple DES should be supported. Add SSL_RSA_WITH_RC4_128_SHA or SSL_RSA_WITH_RC4_128_MD5 only if clients don't support the recommended value.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS – SSL Client DN Match: Set tnsnames file to include SSL_SERVER_CERT_DN parameter with the distinguished name (DN) of the certificate.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Set tnsnames file to include SSL_SERVER_CERT_DN parameter with the distinguished name (DN) of the certificate.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This will reduce possibility of certificate masquerading.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS – SSL Client Authentication: SSL_CLIENT_AUTHENTICATION=TRUE

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If client certificates are not supported in the enterprise, then set to FALSE.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: OAS – Encryption Tab: Use OAS encryption only if SSL is not feasible.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Use OAS encryption only if SSL is not feasible.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: OAS Integrity/Encryption should only be used if required because of non-SSL clients.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Encryption: Where possible, use a procedure that employs a content data element as the encryption key that is unique for each record.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Where possible, use a procedure that employs a content data element as the encryption key that is unique for each record.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: By employing a procedure that uses data elements that change for each record the resulting ciphertext will be unique. As an example if the same value, key, and encryption are used for a value in a record the resulting ciphertext will be identical. Someone knowing the value of one of the records independent of the ciphertext can by inference know the value of other records that display the same ciphertext.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Encryption: Use RAW or BLOB for the storage of encrypted data.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Use RAW or BLOB for the storage of encrypted data.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Storing data in CLOB may result in a failure in decryption if the same number letter symbol set is not used. The use of RAW or BLOBs prevents this error and preserves the data.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select OWNER||'.'||TABLE_NAME from DBA_TAB_COLUMNS where DATA_TYPE ='CLOB' and OWNER not in ( 'ANONYMOUS', 'BI', 'CTXSYS', 'DBSNMP', 'DIP', 'DMSYS', 'EXFSYS', 'HR', 'IX', 'MDDATA', 'MDSYS', 'MGMT_VIEW', 'OE', 'OLAPSYS', 'ORDPLUGINS', 'ORDSYS', 'OUTLN', 'PM', 'SH', 'SI_INFORMTN_SCHEMA', 'SYS', 'SYSMAN', 'SYSTEM', 'WKPROXY', 'WKSYS', 'WK_TEST', 'WMSYS', 'XDB' )

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Encryption: Use a virtual private database (VPD) to protect rows by implementing Oracle Label Security(OLS).

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Use a virtual private database (VPD) to protect rows by implementing Oracle Label Security(OLS).
If keys are stored in a table with the database, access to the keys should be limited and under the protection of a secure role with fine grain auditing in place for the table.
The column name should be obscure and should not reveal the role of the column.
Rows should be protected with both VPD and OLS (OLS included VPD) and the keys themselves should be encrypted with a master key.
If the keys are managed by an application or generated as computed keys the procedures should be wrapped.
All package bodies, procedures, and functions should be wrapped.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Assign multiple layers of protection, within the limits of what can be managed, to ensure the security of the encryption keys. The combination of methods will be dependent on how and where the keys are stored.
Use multiple layers of protection when storing keys with the data in a separate database.
Employ wrapping to protect all code used to protect, generate keys for, or encrypt keys.
If security dictates, hardware devices can be used for encryption key storage.
Keys, at minimum, should follow password selection standards in areas of minimum length, use of special characters and non-dictionary words.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Encryption: Revoke the PUBLIC execute privileges from the DBMS_OBFUSCATION_TOOLKIT.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Revoke the PUBLIC execute privileges from the DBMS_OBFUSCATION_TOOLKIT.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The DBMS_OBFUSCATION_TOOLKIT has been replaced with the DBMS_CRYPTO package, but the DBMS_OBFUSCATION_TOOLKIT is still needed for some tasks that are not Available in the DBMS_CRYPTO package. As an example; the generation of a pseudorandom string requires the DBMS_OBFUSCATION_TOOLKIT. By removing public access to the DBMS_OBFUSCATION_TOOLKIT the means to decrypt the data is not Available for malicious use.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GRANTEE from DBA_TAB_PRIVS where owner = 'SYS' and TABLE_NAME = 'DBMS_OBFUSCATION_TOOLKIT' and GRANTEE = 'PUBLIC'

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Startup and Shutdown
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: These checks define best practices pertaining to the security of an Oracle instance while starting or shutting down.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Advanced queuing in asynchronous messaging: Empty queue at shut down of Oracle.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Empty queue at shut down of Oracle.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Information in queue may be accessed outside of Oracle and beyond the control of the security parameters. It should be subject to the same security precautions as other tables.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Cache: Cache must be emptied at shut down of Oracle.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Cache must be emptied at shut down of Oracle.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Information in caches may be accessed outside of Oracle and beyond the controls of the security parameters.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: ASM: Ensure that the ASM is started first and shut down last

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Ensure that the ASM is started first and shut down last

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Ensure that the Automated Storage Management (ASM), new to Oracle 10g, is started first and shut down last. Databases cannot mount their data files until the ASM instance is started, and will crash if the ASM instance is shut down before dependent databases are unmounted. This could cause loss of availability and possible database corruption.
Note that this problem is fixed by patching to version 10.1.0.3 or higher.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Backup and Disaster Recovery
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: In the event of a catastrophic failure these items will help ensure the integrity of an Oracle installation.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Redo logs: Mirror

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The on-line redo logs must be mirrored and more than one group must exist.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GROUP# from V$LOG where MEMBERS > 1

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Control files: Multiplex control files to multiple physical disks.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Multiplex control files to multiple physical disks.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Redundancy for the control files can prevent catastrophic loss in the event of a single physical drive failure.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Control files: Mirror

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The control files must be mirrored.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select VALUE from V$SYSTEM_PARAMETER2 where NAME = 'control_files'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Archive logs: Ensure there is sufficient space for the archive logging process.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Ensure there is sufficient space for the archive logging process.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Without adequate space for the archive logs the system will hang.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Redo logs: Multiplex redo logs to multiple physical disks.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Multiplex redo logs to multiple physical disks.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Redundancy for the redo logs can prevent catastrophic loss in the event of a single physical drive failure.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Archive log files: Backup

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If archivelog mode is used the archive log files must be saved on tape or to a separate disk. File permissions must be restricted to the owner of the Oracle software and the dba group. The archive logs must be secured.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Backup: Automated backups should be verified.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Oracle 10g streamlines backups with new automated services. Backups should be verified by performing recoveries to ensure newer automated backups function properly. Failure to ensure this could cause inability to recover data, leading to data loss. The improved RMAN (Recovery Manager) capabilities (i.e., incremental backup process) can be used to facilitate backups and recovery.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Failsafe: Failsafe must be engaged.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Failsafe uses the cluster server interface to provide the failover protection previously provided by hardware interfaces.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Oracle Profile (User) Setup Settings
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: The Oracle profiles must have resonable measures associated with the prevention of account access and password lifetime. These items test the robustness of the oracle authentication and profile security.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Database Profiles: failed_login_attempts=3

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Local policy may override the recommended setting. This setting may not be applicable for middle tier application accounts that access the database. Application accounts must be set for failed_login_attempts=1.
Create a profile then assign it to a user account. Default profile has this setting at 10.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select PROFILE from DBA_PROFILES where RESOURCE_NAME = 'FAILED_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS' and LIMIT != '3'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Database Profiles: password_life_time= 90

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Local policy may not override the setting. This setting may not be applicable for middle tier application accounts that access the database.
Create a profile then assign it to a user account. Default profile has this setting not set.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select PROFILE from DBA_PROFILES where RESOURCE_NAME = 'PASSWORD_LIFE_TIME' and LIMIT != '90'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Database Profiles: password_reuse_max=20

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Local policy may override the recommended setting. This setting may not be applicable for middle tier application accounts that access the database.
Create a profile then assign it to a user account. Default profile has this setting not set.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select PROFILE from DBA_PROFILES where RESOURCE_NAME = 'PASSWORD_REUSE_MAX' and LIMIT != '20'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Database Profiles: password_reuse_time= 365

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Local policy may not override the setting. This setting must be set to unlimited if a password_reuse_max value other than unlimited is defined for Oracle versions earlier than 9i. See Metalink DocID 228991.1 to see the Oracle version-specific relationship of this setting with the password_reuse_max setting.
Create a profile then assign it to a user account. Default profile has this setting not set.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select PROFILE from DBA_PROFILES where RESOURCE_NAME = 'PASSWORD_REUSE_TIME' and LIMIT != '365'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Database Profiles: password_lock_time=1

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Local policy may not override the setting. This setting may not be applicable for middle tier application accounts that access the database.
Create a profile then assign it to a user account. Default profile has this set to unlimited.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select PROFILE from DBA_PROFILES where RESOURCE_NAME = 'PASSWORD_LOCK_TIME' and LIMIT != '1'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Database Profiles: password_grace_time=3

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Local policy may not override the setting. This setting may not be applicable for middle tier application accounts that access the database.
Create a profile then assign it to a user account. Default profile has this setting not set.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select PROFILE from DBA_PROFILES where RESOURCE_NAME = 'PASSWORD_GRACE_TIME' and LIMIT != '3'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Database Profiles: Review accounts where PASSWORD= 'EXTERNAL'

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Check and review any user who has password='EXTERNAL'. Do not allow remote OS authentication to the database.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select USERNAME from DBA_USERS where PASSWORD = 'EXTERNAL' and ACCOUNT_STATUS != 'LOCKED'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Database Profiles: Set password_verify_function to a verification function

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Set password_verify_function to a verification function

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allows password verification function to be called when passwords are changed. This always works for password changes via the “password” command at an SQL prompt. It may or may not work with the ALTER USER command. This setting may not be applicable for middle tier application accounts that access the database. Oracle provides utlpwdmg.sql which can be used to create a password verification function. If using this script to create a password verification function, make the following changes at the bottom of the utlpwdmg.sql file:
PASSWORD_GRACE_TIME 3
PASSWORD_REUSE_TIME 365
PASSWORD_REUSE_MAX 20
FAILED_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS 3
PASSWORD_LOCK_TIME 1
Modify the line: IF length(password) < 4
by changing the minimum password length to 8.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select PROFILE from DBA_PROFILES where RESOURCE_NAME = 'PASSWORD_VERIFY_FUNCTION' and LIMIT = 'NULL'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Database Profiles: Set CPU_PER_SESSION as appropriate

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Ensure that users profile settings have appropriate values set for the particular database and application.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Ensure that users profile settings have appropriate values set for the particular database and application.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Oracle Profile (User) Access Settings
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: The Oracle user account profiles should maintain minimum rights and access test items test to integrity of roles access and authorization.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Tablespaces: Do not have default_tablespace set to SYSTEM for user accounts

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Do not have default_tablespace set to SYSTEM for user accounts

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Only SYS should have a default tablespace of SYSTEM. It may be difficult or impossible to move some objects.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select USERNAME from DBA_USERS where USERNAME not in ('SYS', 'SYSTEM', 'OUTLN') and DEFAULT_TABLESPACE = 'SYSTEM'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Tablespaces: Ensure application users have not been granted quotas on tablespaces.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Set quotas for developers on shared production/development systems to prevent space resource contentions.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Prevent assignment of roles that have _CATALOG_

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Revoke any catalog roles from those roles and users that do not need them. These roles are SELECT_CATALOG_ROLE, EXECUTE_CATALOG_ROLE, DELETE_CATALOG_ROLE, and RECOVERY_CATALOG_OWNER.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GRANTEE from DBA_ROLE_PRIVS where GRANTED_ROLE like '%_CATALOG_%' and GRANTEE not in ( 'DBA', 'EXP_FULL_DATABASE', 'IMP_FULL_DATABASE', 'IX', 'MDSYS', 'OLAP_DBA', 'OLAP_USER', 'SH', 'SYS', 'WKUSER' )

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Synonyms: Prevent access to any V$ synonym

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Prevent access to any V$ synonym

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Check for any user that has access and revoke where possible.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select distinct GRANTEE from DBA_TAB_PRIVS where OWNER = 'SYS' and table_name like 'V$%' and grantee not in ('SYS', 'DBA')

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Synonyms: When dropping synonyms, ensure privileges granted to the synonyms, if not required, are removed from the base objects.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: When dropping synonyms, ensure privileges granted to the synonyms, if not required, are removed from the base objects.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Granting privileges to synonyms actually grants privileges to the base objects. If necessary, ensure that privileges from the base objects are removed when the synonyms are dropped.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Privileges: Restrict system privileges

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: All system privileges except for CREATE SESSION must be restricted to DBAs, application object owner accounts/schemas (locked accounts) and default Oracle accounts. Developers may be granted limited system privileges as required on development databases.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select * from DBA_SYS_PRIVS where privilege != 'CREATE SESSION' and GRANTEE not in ( 'AQ_ADMINISTRATOR_ROLE', 'DBA', 'DBSNMP', 'EXFSYS', 'EXP_FULL_DATABASE', 'IMP_FULL_DATABASE', 'IX', 'JAVADEBUGPRIV', 'MDSYS', 'OEM_MONITOR', 'OLAPSYS', 'OLAP_DBA', 'ORDPLUGINS', 'ORDSYS', 'OUTLN', 'SCHEDULER_ADMIN', 'SYS', 'SYSMAN', 'SYSTEM', 'WKSYS' ) order by GRANTEE

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Privileges: Prevent granting of privileges that contain the keyword ANY

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Prevent granting of privileges that contain the keyword ANY

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Check for any user or role that has the “ANY” keyword and revoke this role where possible.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GRANTEE from DBA_SYS_PRIVS where privilege like '%ANY%' and GRANTEE not in ( 'AQ_ADMINISTRATOR_ROLE', 'DBA', 'DBSNMP', 'EXFSYS', 'EXP_FULL_DATABASE', 'IMP_FULL_DATABASE', 'IX', 'JAVADEBUGPRIV', 'MDSYS', 'OEM_MONITOR', 'OLAPSYS', 'OLAP_DBA', 'ORDPLUGINS', 'ORDSYS', 'OUTLN', 'SCHEDULER_ADMIN', 'SYS', 'SYSMAN', 'SYSTEM', 'WKSYS' )

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Privileges: Prevent granting of ALL PRIVILEGES

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES must not be used.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Privileges: Prevent granting of EXEMPT ACCESS POLICY (EAP)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Prevent granting of EXEMPT ACCESS POLICY (EAP)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Revoke this privilege if not necessary.
The EAP privilege provides access to all rows regardless of Row Level Security assigned to specific rows.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GRANTEE from DBA_SYS_PRIVS where PRIVILEGE = 'EXEMPT ACCESS POLICY'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Privileges: Prevent granting of privileges that have WITH ADMIN

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Prevent granting of privileges that have WITH ADMIN

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Check for any user or role that has been granted privileges “with admin” and revoke where possible.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GRANTEE from DBA_SYS_PRIVS where ADMIN_OPTION = 'YES' and GRANTEE not in ('AQ_ADMINISTRATOR_ROLE', 'DBA', 'SCHEDULER_ADMIN', 'SYS', 'SYSTEM' )

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Privileges: Prevent granting of privileges that have WITH GRANT

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Prevent granting of privileges that have WITH GRANT

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Check for any user or role that has been granted privileges “with grant” and revoke where possible.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select * from DBA_TAB_PRIVS where GRANTABLE = 'YES' and GRANTEE not in ( 'CTXSYS', 'MDSYS', 'OLAPSYS', 'ORDSYS', 'PUBLIC', 'SYS', 'SYSMAN', 'SYSTEM', 'WMSYS' )

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Privileges: Prevent granting of privileges that have CREATE

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Prevent granting of privileges that have CREATE

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Check for any user that has object creation privileges and revoke where possible.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select * from DBA_SYS_PRIVS where privilege like 'CREATE%' and GRANTEE not in ( 'ANONYMOUS', 'AQ_ADMINISTRATOR_ROLE', 'CONNECT', 'CTXSYS', 'DBA', 'DIP', 'DMSYS', 'EXFSYS', 'IMP_FULL_DATABASE', 'IX', 'MDSYS', 'MGMT_USER', 'OE', 'OEM_MONITOR', 'OLAPSYS', 'OLAP_DBA', 'OLAP_USER', 'ORDPLUGINS', 'ORDSYS', 'RECOVERY_CATALOG_OWNER', 'RESOURCE', 'SCHEDULER_ADMIN', 'SH', 'SYS', 'SYSMAN', 'SYSTEM', 'WKPROXY', 'WKSYS', 'WKUSER', 'WMSYS', 'XDB' )

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Privileges: Prevent granting of CREATE LIBRARY

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Check for any user or role that has this privilege and revoke where possible.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GRANTEE from DBA_SYS_PRIVS where privilege = 'CREATE_LIBRARY' and GRANTEE not in ( 'DBA', 'EXFSYS', 'MDSYS', 'OLAPSYS', 'ORDPLUGINS', 'ORDSYS', 'SYS', 'WKSYS', 'XDB' )

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Privileges: Prevent granting of ALTER SYSTEM

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Check for any user or role that has this privilege and revoke where possible.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GRANTEE from DBA_SYS_PRIVS where privilege = 'ALTER_SYSTEM' and GRANTEE not in ('DBA', 'DMSYS', 'SYS', 'WKSYS' )

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Privileges: Prevent granting of CREATE_PROCEDURE

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Check for any user or role that has this privilege and revoke where possible.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GRANTEE from DBA_SYS_PRIVS where privilege = 'CREATE_PROCEDURE' and GRANTEE not in ( 'DBA', 'DMSYS', 'IX', 'MDSYS', 'OLAPSYS', 'OLAP_USER', 'ORDPLUGINS', 'ORDSYS', 'RECOVERY_CATALOG_OWNER', 'RESOURCE', 'SYS', 'WKSYS' )

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Privileges: Prevent granting of BECOME_USER

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Check for any user or role that has this privilege and revoke where possible.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GRANTEE from DBA_SYS_PRIVS where privilege = 'BECOME_USER' and GRANTEE not in ( 'DBA', 'IMP_FULL_DATABASE', 'SYS', 'WKSYS' )

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Privileges: Prevent granting of SELECT_ANY_TABLE

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Check for any user that has access and revoke where possible. If application data is sensitive, and it is possible, revoke this privilege from the DBA accounts as well.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GRANTEE from DBA_SYS_PRIVS where privilege = 'SELECT_ANY_TABLE' and GRANTEE not in ('DBA', 'EXP_FULL_DATABASE', 'IMP_FULL_DATABASE', 'OLAPSYS', 'OLAP_DBA', 'SYS', 'SYSTEM', 'WKSYS' )

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Privileges: Prevent granting of AUDIT_SYSTEM

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Review which users have audit system privileges and limit as much as possible to ensure audit commands are not revoked.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GRANTEE from DBA_SYS_PRIVS where privilege = 'AUDIT_SYSTEM' and GRANTEE not in ('DBA', 'SYS', 'WKSYS' )

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Privileges: Grant privileges only to roles.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Grant privileges only to roles. Do not grant privileges to individual users.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select distinct GRANTEE from DBA_ROLE_PRIVS where GRANTEE in (select USERNAME from DBA_USERS) and GRANTEE not in ( 'BI', 'CTXSYS', 'DBSNMP', 'DIP', 'DMSYS', 'EXFSYS', 'HR', 'IX', 'MDDATA', 'MDSYS', 'MGMT_VIEW', 'OE', 'OLAPSYS', 'ORDPLUGINS', 'ORDSYS', 'OUTLN', 'PM', 'SH', 'SI_INFORMTN_SCHEMA', 'SYS', 'SYSMAN' )

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Privileges: Review privileges granted to PUBLIC

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GRANTEE from DBA_SYS_PRIVS where GRANTEE = 'PUBLIC'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Roles: Prevent assignment of RESOURCE

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GRANTEE from DBA_SYS_PRIVS where privilege = 'RESOURCE'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Roles: Prevent assignment of CONNECT

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Revoke connect role from normal application user accounts.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GRANTEE from DBA_SYS_PRIVS where privilege = 'CONNECT'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Roles: Prevent assignment of DBA

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Revoke dba role from users who do not require it.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Revoke the public execute privilege on utl_file as it can be used to access O/S
Only sys has privilege by default.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GRANTEE from DBA_TAB_PRIVS where OWNER = 'SYS' and TABLE_NAME = 'UTL_FILE' and GRANTEE = 'PUBLIC'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Packages: Deny access to UTL_TCP

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Revoke the public execute privilege on utl_tcp as it can write and read sockets.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Packages: Deny access to UTL_HTTP

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Packages: Deny access to DBMS_LOB

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GRANTEE from DBA_TAB_PRIVS where OWNER = 'SYS' and TABLE_NAME = 'DBMS_LOB' and GRANTEE = 'PUBLIC'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Packages: Deny access to DBMS_SYS_SQL

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Revoke the public execute privilege.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GRANTEE from DBA_TAB_PRIVS where OWNER = 'SYS' and TABLE_NAME = 'DBMS_SYS_SQL' and GRANTEE = 'PUBLIC'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Packages: Deny access to DBMS_JOB

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Proxy Authentication: Limit the user schema privileges to “CREATE SESSION” only.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Limit the user schema privileges to “CREATE SESSION” only.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The proxy account should only have the ability to connect to the database. No other privileges should be granted to this account.
Set when creating the proxy account.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select distinct GRANTEE from DBA_ROLE_PRIVS where GRANTED_ROLE != 'CREATE SESSION' and GRANTEE in (select USERNAME from DBA_USERS) and GRANTEE not in ( 'BI', 'CTXSYS', 'DBSNMP', 'DIP', 'DMSYS', 'EXFSYS', 'HR', 'IX', 'MDDATA', 'MDSYS', 'MGMT_VIEW', 'OE', 'OLAPSYS', 'ORDPLUGINS', 'ORDSYS', 'OUTLN', 'PM', 'SH', 'SI_INFORMTN_SCHEMA', 'SYS', 'SYSMAN' )

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Proxy role: Restrict the roles that can be enabled when privileges are granted in the database. As an example;

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Restrict the roles that can be enabled when privileges are granted in the database. As an example;
“ALTER USER JOHN_SMITH DEFAULT ROLE ALL EXCEPT X”

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Assuming John Smith needs only the role of ‘X', then all other roles are prevented from being enabled.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Tables: Do not store passwords in clear text in Oracle tables

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Do not store passwords in clear text in Oracle tables

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Passwords stored by applications in the database tables must be encrypted. Access to these tables must be limited.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Tables: Encrypt critical data

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Critical data must be encrypted to prevent the DBA from accessing it. Alternately, audit key tables. This does not prevent the DBA from viewing the data, but would create a record of the activity. Management of the encryption key must be done carefully as exposure of the key will render the encryption moot.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Views: Revoke public access to all public views that start with ALL_

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Revoke public access to all public views that start with ALL_

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Revoke access to these views when possible. This may interfere with some applications.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select * from DBA_TAB_PRIVS where OWNER = 'SYS' and table_name like 'ALL%' and GRANTEE = 'PUBLIC'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Roles: Password protect roles

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Role passwords are useful when an application controls whether or not a role is turned on. This prevents a user directly accessing the database via SQL (rather than through the application) from being able to enable the privileges associated with the role.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select ROLE from DBA_ROLES where password_required != 'YES' and role not in ('AQ_ADMINISTRATOR_ROLE', 'AQ_USER_ROLE', 'AUTHENTICATEDUSER', 'CONNECT', 'CTXAPP', 'DBA', 'DELETE_CATALOG_ROLE', 'DMUSER_ROLE', 'DM_CATALOG_ROLE', 'EJBCLIENT', 'EXECUTE_CATALOG_ROLE', 'EXP_FULL_DATABASE', 'GATHER_SYSTEM_STATISTICS', 'GLOBAL_AQ_USER_ROLE', 'HS_ADMIN_ROLE', 'IMP_FULL_DATABASE', 'JAVADEBUGPRIV', 'JAVAIDPRIV', 'JAVASYSPRIV', 'JAVAUSERPRIV', 'JAVA_ADMIN', 'JAVA_DEPLOY', 'LOGSTDBY_ADMINISTRATOR', 'MGMT_USER', 'OEM_MONITOR', 'OLAP_DBA', 'OLAP_USER', 'RECOVERY_CATALOG_OWNER', 'RESOURCE', 'SCHEDULER_ADMIN', 'SELECT_CATALOG_ROLE', 'WKUSER', 'WM_ADMIN_ROLE', 'XDBADMIN' )

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Roles and Privileges: When dropping a user, ensure roles and privileges created by that user, if not required, are deleted.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: When dropping a user, ensure roles and privileges created by that user, if not required, are deleted.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If a user is dropped, ensure that the roles and privileges created by that user, if not required, are deleted. Dropping a user (i.e., DROP USER X CASCADE) doesn't delete roles and privileges created by the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Packages: Limit or deny access to dbms_backup_restore

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Limit or deny access to dbms_backup_restore

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Provides file system functions such as copying files, altering control files, accessing devices, and deleting files.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GRANTEE from DBA_TAB_PRIVS where OWNER = 'SYS' and TABLE_NAME = 'DBMS_BACKUP_RESTORE'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Packages: Limit or deny access to DBMS_RANDOM

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Limit or deny access to DBMS_RANDOM

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Revoke the public execute privilege.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select GRANTEE from DBA_TAB_PRIVS where OWNER = 'SYS' and TABLE_NAME = 'DBMS_RANDOM' and GRANTEE = 'PUBLIC'

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Enterprise Manager / Grid Control / Agents
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: These items test the best recommended practices for running the OEM or Grid control software in an 11g environment

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Enterprise Management studio mode: Access to the enterprise management in studio must be limited.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Access to the enterprise management in studio must be limited.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Without limitations on the enterprise management access to the remote agents is virtually unlimited.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Enterprise Manager Agent File uploads: Monitor the size of file uploads from the enterprise agent.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Monitor the size of file uploads from the enterprise agent.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The following lines are some of the output from the ./emctl status agent command containing information regarding the agents uploading files:
Total Megabytes of XML files uploaded so far : Number of XML files pending upload:
Size of XML files pending upload(MB):
Discovering unusual or increased size of file uploads could indicate a malicious agent.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Enterprise Manager Framework Security: Where possible, utilize Enterprise Manager Framework Security Functionality.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Where possible, utilize Enterprise Manager Framework Security Functionality.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Enterprise Manager Framework security employs secure communication between the various Enterprise Manager Components, i.e., HTTPS between management agents and management services.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Grid Control TimeOut Value: Configure an appropriate value for Grid Control Timeout value in the Oracle Application Server.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Configure an appropriate value for Grid Control Timeout value in the Oracle Application Server.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: To prevent unauthorized access to the Grid Control via browser, set an appropriate timeout value. A recommended value of 30 minutes or less is recommended.
The default is 45 minutes.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Enterprise Manager Framework Security: In command line mode, avoid using commands that contain passwords in the arguments.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: In command line mode, avoid using commands that contain passwords in the arguments.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: While registering an agent to utilize the enterprise manager framework security, avoid using the complete command line arguments for the emctl command.
The command can be captured by other users with access to unix (via ps) command or can be prone to shoulder surfing.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Oracle Installation: Separate user account for Management/Intelligent Agent

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Separate user account for Management/Intelligent Agent

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: For Unix systems, create a unique user account for the management/Intelligent Agent process in order to differentiate accountability and file access controls. The agent database accounts must be separated. Separate accounts are not recommended for Windows environments.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: 10g Specific Systems
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: Test items are for specific modules additional to the Oracle 10g

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: ADDM: Verify ADDM suggestions

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Oracle 10g's new automated diagnostics through the Automatic Database Diagnostic Monitor (ADDM), should not blindly replace the DBA's knowledge. DBA's should verify the applicability of ADDM suggestions based on their knowledge of the database.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: AMM: Monitor AMM

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Oracle 10g's new Automated Memory Manager (AMM), should not blindly replace the DBA's knowledge. DBA's should monitor AMM to ensure memory is being properly allocated.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: AWR: Implement AWR to record all database performance statistics (related to object usage, SQL statement efficiency, session history, etc) over a defined time period.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Implement AWR to record all database performance statistics (related to object usage, SQL statement efficiency, session history, etc) over a defined time period.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Automatic Workload repository (AWR) is central to the whole framework of self and automatic management. It works with internal Oracle database components to process, maintain, and access performance statistics for problem detection and self-tuning. The statistics are Available to external users or performance monitoring tools, routines, or scripts. Trends analysis can be done with AWR data. Queries that overtax the system could be a security threat.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select ROWNUM from V$STATISTICS_LEVEL where SESSION_SETTABLE='NO' and SYSTEM_STATUS='DISABLED'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Fine grained access: Use fine grain access control within objects.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Use fine grain access control within objects.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Fine grained access control can provide both column and row level security. This can provide an additional layer of access control to objects by limiting the access (select, update, insert, delete) within the object and should be used wherever possible. For fine grained access to function properly, use the cost-based optimizer.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: General Policy and Procedures
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: These items test the general management and security policies of the Oracle 9i and 10g system

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Oracle alert log file: Review contents

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The Oracle alert log file must be regularly reviewed for errors.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Database creation scripts on host: Remove or secure

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: After the database has been created, remove the scripts or at a minimum move them to a safe repository area.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Unix root group members on host: Disallow 'oracle' as member of root group

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Disallow 'oracle' as member of root group

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The Oracle software owner account must not be a member of the root group on Unix systems.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Oracle DBA group membership on host: Review

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Review the membership of the DBA group on the host to ensure that only authorized accounts are included. This must be limited to users who require DBA access.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Sensitive information in process list on host: Avoid or encrypt

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: An enforced policy must exist to ensure that no scripts are running that display sensitive information in the process list such as the Oracle username and password. A privileged process must be used to get and decrypt encrypted passwords.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Sensitive information in cron jobs on host: Avoid or encrypt

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: An enforced policy must exist to ensure that no cron jobs have sensitive information such as database username and passwords. A privileged process must be used to get and decrypt encrypted passwords.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Sensitive information in at jobs (or jobs in Windows scheduler) on host: Avoid or encrypt

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: An enforced policy must exist to ensure that no at jobs (or jobs in Windows scheduler) has sensitive information such as database username and passwords. A privileged process must be used to get and decrypt encrypted passwords.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Sensitive information in environment variables on host: Avoid or encrypt

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: An enforced policy must exist to ensure that no users have unencrypted sensitive information such as database username and passwords set in environment variables. A privileged process must be used to get and decrypt encrypted passwords.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Sensitive information in batch files on host: Avoid or encrypt

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: An enforced policy must exist to ensure that no batch files have unencrypted sensitive information such as database username and passwords. A privileged process must be used to get and decrypt encrypted passwords.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Oracle file locations: Separate for performance

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Split the location of the Oracle software distribution, redo logs, data files, and indexes onto separate disks and controllers for resilience.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: File systems: Separate Oracle files from non-Oracle files

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Separate Oracle files from non-Oracle files

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Only put database files on file systems exclusively used by Oracle. Oracle files must not be on the same partition as the operating system.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Optimal Flexible Architecture: Implement

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Follow the Oracle Optimal Flexible Architecture guidelines to provide for consistency and ease of administration.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Checksum PL/SQL code: Implement

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Store the checksum results and periodically check for alterations.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: All database objects: Monitor

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Store the results of the time stamps of the creation, reload, and compilation of database objects and review the results regularly to ensure no unauthorized changes have occurred.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ad-hoc queries on production databases: Avoid

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Disallow ad-hoc queries on production databases. This recommendation may not be suitable for all environments, for example, data warehouses.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Media integrity: Verify

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Backup media integrity must be checked regularly.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Remote shell access on host: Encrypt session

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If remote shell access is required, use ssh or a VPN solution to ensure that session traffic is encrypted. In a cluster environment (RAC or OPS) rsh and rcp are required between the nodes for the Oracle software owner. In the case of a cluster environment, the access must be restricted by user and host.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Applications with database access: Review

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Review and control which applications access the database.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Location of development database: Separate server from production database

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Test and development databases must not be located on the same server as the production system.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Network location of production and development databases: Separate

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If possible, place production databases on a different network segment from test and development databases.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Monitor for development on production databases: Prevent development on production databases

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Check for evidence of development occurring on production databases.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Access to production databases: Avoid access from development or test databases

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Avoid access from development or test databases

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Database access from development and test databases to production databases must be prohibited.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Developer access to production databases: Disallow

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Developers must not have direct access to production databases.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Developer accounts on production databases: Remove

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Remove any developer accounts that exist in the production database.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Databases created from production exports: Change passwords

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If test or development databases are created from backups or exports of the production system, all passwords must be changed before granting access to developers or testers.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Databases created from production systems: Remove sensitive data

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If test or development databases are created from backups or exports of the production system, all sensitive data (such as payroll information) must be removed before granting access to developers or testers.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Account Management: Document and enforce account management procedures

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Document and enforce account management procedures

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Create and regularly review procedures for account management. This must include the creation of new user accounts, moving a user to a new group or role, and handling of dormant or inactive accounts.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Change Control: Document and enforce change control procedures

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Document and enforce change control procedures

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Create and regularly review procedures for new applications that access the database and change control management procedures for releasing development code into production. Monitor the addition of new users and access rights.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Disaster recovery procedures: Review

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Disaster recovery procedures must be fully documented and regularly tested.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Backdoors: Eliminate

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Tight change control management procedures and checksums of the source code can help prevent backdoors into the database.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Public dissemination of database information: Disallow

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The posting database information such as SIDs, hostnames, and IP addresses to newsgroups and mailing lists must not be allowed.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Screen saver: Set screen saver/lock with password protection of 15 minutes.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Set screen saver/lock with password protection of 15 minutes.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If an organizational policy does not exist, 15 minutes must be set as the standard.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Distribution of tnsnames.ora files to clients: Include only necessary tnsnames.ora when distributing to clients

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Include only necessary tnsnames.ora when distributing to clients

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If clients connect to the database using tnsnames.ora files, ensure that only necessary entries are included in the file when distributing to clients.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Put database in archivelog mode (if appropriate to database function).: If the database was not created in archivelog mode, start the database in mount mode, and issue: alter database achivelog;

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: If the database was not created in archivelog mode, start the database in mount mode, and issue: alter database achivelog;

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If archive log mode is used, transmission of archive logs must be secured as LogMiner could be used to extract database information from the archive logs.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select LOG_MODE from V$DATABASE where LOG_MODE = 'ARCHIVELOG'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Event and System Logs: Monitor

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Windows Event Logs and Unix System logs must be regularly monitored for errors related to the Oracle database.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Access to database objects by a fixed user link: Disallow

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Fixed user database links that have a hard coded username and password must be avoided.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select DB_LINK from DBA_DB_LINKS where USERNAME is not null

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Oracle Installation: Oracle software owner account name NOT ‘oracle'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Oracle software owner account name NOT ‘oracle'

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Do not name the Oracle software owner account ‘oracle' as it is very well known.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Oracle Installation: Separate users for different components of Oracle

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Separate users for different components of Oracle

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: For Unix systems, create unique user accounts for each Oracle process/service in order to differentiate accountability and file access controls. The listener, the Oracle http server, and the database process accounts must be separate. Separate accounts are not recommended for Windows environments. The requirement for the Management/Intelligent Agent process is listed in section 10 of this document.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Alerts on high priority incidents: Create processes to alert

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Create processes to monitor and alert of high priority incidents.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Intelligent agent: Do not use

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If the database server is accessible via the Internet, do not use the Intelligent Agent. This may not be practical for OEM or SNMP monitored databases.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Oracle Advanced Security: Implement if appropriate

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If appropriate to the environment, implement Oracle Advanced Security to encrypt all traffic between the client and server.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Application PL/SQL code: Wrap

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The wrap program provided by Oracle encodes the PL/SQL source code but does not encrypt it.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: PL/SQL code variables and constants: Obscure

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The wrap program does not encode variables and constants.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Hard coded data in PL/SQL code: Avoid or encrypt

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Do not use unencrypted hard coded usernames, passwords, or other critical data in the PL/SQL code.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Decommissioned applications: Remove all components

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Ensure that all associated binaries, users, batch process, and access rights are removed when applications are decommissioned.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Usernames and passwords: Do not hardcode in application source code

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Do not hardcode in application source code

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Do not hard code usernames and passwords in application source code. Set username and passwords in an encrypted external file or database table.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: DDL statements in application: Disallow

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Applications must not alter the database schema.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Reporting tool interface and authentication: Review

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Any remote access to the database host must be controlled by an application level firewall.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Enabling of batch process account: Time enabled

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The account that is used to run batch processes must be enabled only during the time that the batch processes run.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Passwords for batch processes: Secure

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Passwords for batch processes must not be a command line parameter or an environment variable.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: External account access for batch processes: Disallow

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: External accounts used for batch processes allow a simple way to access the database.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Object and table owners: Review

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Identify the owner of all objects and tables that make up an application.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Data in development database: Protect

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If data is imported from a production database to development or test databases, ensure that any sensitive data (i.e. payroll information) is not accessible to users of the development or test databases.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Database links to production databases: Avoid links from development database

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Database links from development and test databases to production databases must be forbidden.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: User permissions: Review

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Review and test development databases for users with excess permissions not granted in production.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Procedures for backup tape retrieval: Review

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Ensure the procedures for backup tape retrieval are documented and are adequate to prevent social engineering attacks to steal data.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Intrusion detection system on host: Utilize

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Use a host based Intrusion Detection System on the server hosting the Oracle database.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Multiple listeners: Create separate listeners for clients and administration. Protect the administrative listener with IPSec ESP or OAS SSL and a personal firewall.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Create separate listeners for clients and administration. Protect the administrative listener with IPSec ESP or OAS SSL and a personal firewall.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: An administrative listener, protected by IPSec, could allow administrators access to the server if the client listener(s) are taken down. Preference of implementation is IPSec ESP, otherwise SSL and personal firewall. If SSL is not possible, use OAS native encryption/integrity with a personal firewall, otherwise use a personal firewall. Access must be limited to specific administrative workstations.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Remote Administration of Listener: Configure listener to have an SSL port.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Configure listener to have an SSL port.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If remote administration of a listener via the listener utility is required, e.g., no administration through SSH or MS Terminal Server, configure the listener to have a TCPS (SSL) port. If the listener is configured to use multiple protocols, set the SSL protocol as the first protocol in listener.ora.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Policy Caching: Policy caches must be purged.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Policy caches can potentially store information that could be used to compromise the database and may accessible outside of Oracle and beyond the control of the security parameters. Hence this can defeat row level security.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Policy Functions: Users should not have execute, alter or drop privileges on policy functions.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Users should not have execute, alter or drop privileges on policy functions.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The ability to manipulate policy functions could be used to defeat row level security.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select * from DBA_POLICIES dp where exists (select null from DBA_OBJECTS do, DBA_TAB_PRIVS dtp where do.OBJECT_TYPE = 'PACKAGE' and do.OBJECT_NAME = dp.PACKAGE and dtp.TABLE_NAME = do.OBJECT_NAME and dtp.PRIVILEGE in ('EXECUTE','ALTER','DROP') and dtp.GRANTEE not in ('ANONYMOUS', 'BI', 'CTXSYS', 'DBSNMP', 'DIP', 'DMSYS', 'EXFSYS', 'HR', 'IX', 'MDDATA', 'MDSYS', 'MGMT_VIEW', 'OE', 'OLAPSYS', 'ORDPLUGINS', 'ORDSYS', 'OUTLN', 'PM', 'SH', 'SI_INFORMTN_SCHEMA', 'SYS', 'SYSMAN' ) )

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Passwords: Remove password parameters from configuration files utilized for Silent Installations.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Remove password parameters from configuration files utilized for Silent Installations.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Whenever utilizing silent installs, i.e., Oracle Installer, ensure configuration files do not contain password values after the installation completes.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Security of transmitted data: Any data sent over a network must be secure or must be sent via a secure protocol.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Any data sent over a network must be secure or must be sent via a secure protocol.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Data sent over a network can reveal significant information. Any data should be secure. If the network structure itself is not secure, data must be sent via a secure protocol.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Auditing Policy and Procedures
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: This section of items test the robustness of the audition configuration.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Auditing: Unused schemas should be dropped

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Unused schemas should be first audited to ensure that they are in fact unused. After verification, they should be dropped.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Auditing: Trap autonomous transactions

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This will ensure that audit captures actions performed by users even if they are later rolled back.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Auditing: Audit all log ons and log offs.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Audit all log ons and log offs.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This is the minimum of auditing and the auditing must be configured to show who logged on/off.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select * from DBA_STMT_AUDIT_OPTS where AUDIT_OPTION = 'CREATE SESSION' and USER_NAME is null and PROXY_NAME is null and SUCCESS = 'BY ACCESS' and FAILURE = 'BY ACCESS'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Auditing: Audit for unsuccessful attempts. Audit by “ACCESS WHENEVER NOT SUCCESSFUL”.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Audit for unsuccessful attempts. Audit by “ACCESS WHENEVER NOT SUCCESSFUL”.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Auditing by SESSION will only show a single audit event for an attempt. By logging unsuccessful attempts any SQL statement attempting to access the table will be recorded. This could provide a record of unauthorized attempts to access sensitive data.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select ROWNUM from (select null from DBA_STMT_AUDIT_OPTS where SUCCESS != 'BY ACCESS' and FAILURE != 'BY ACCESS' union select null from DBA_PRIV_AUDIT_OPTS where SUCCESS != 'BY ACCESS' and FAILURE != 'BY ACCESS' union select null from DBA_OBJ_AUDIT_OPTS where ALT not like '%/A' and AUD not like '%/A' and COM not like '%/A' and DEL not like '%/A' and GRA not like '%/A' and IND not like '%/A' and INS not like '%/A' and LOC not like '%/A' and REN not like '%/A' and SEL not like '%/A' and UPD not like '%/A' and FBK not like '%/A')

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Auditing: Where appropriate or required by security or legal requirements, engage and use the Fine-Grained Auditing feature.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Where appropriate or required by security or legal requirements, engage and use the Fine-Grained Auditing feature.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Because the FGA record entry can be pre-qualified, it should not add a significant burden to the size of audit records. The flexibility, column specific sensitivity, capture of the SQL, and the event handler combine to make it a valuable asset.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select ROWNUM from (select null from DBA_AUDIT_POLICIES union select null from DBA_AUDIT_POLICY_COLUMNS)

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Auditing: Where appropriate or required by security or legal requirements, use enhanced capabilities of Fine-Grained Auditing.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Where appropriate or required by security or legal requirements, use enhanced capabilities of Fine-Grained Auditing.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Fine Grain Auditing (FGA) in Oracle 10g can now audit all types of Data Manipulation Language (DML) statements, not just SELECT. Consider using this to enhance current auditing capabilities. FGA can also optionally execute procedures. For instance, a procedure could perform an action such as sending an e-mail alert to an auditor when a user selects a certain row from a table, or it could write to a different audit trail.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select ROWNUM from (select null from DBA_AUDIT_POLICIES union select null from DBA_AUDIT_POLICY_COLUMNS)

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Auditing: Audit ALTER ANY TABLE

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Audit the use of ALTER ANY TABLE.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select ROWNUM from DBA_STMT_AUDIT_OPTS where AUDIT_OPTION = 'ALTER ANY TABLE' and USER_NAME is null and PROXY_NAME is null and SUCCESS = 'BY ACCESS' and FAILURE = 'BY ACCESS'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Auditing: Audit ALTER USER

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Audit the use of ALTER USER.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select ROWNUM from DBA_STMT_AUDIT_OPTS where AUDIT_OPTION = 'ALTER USER' and USER_NAME is null and PROXY_NAME is null and SUCCESS = 'BY ACCESS' and FAILURE = 'BY ACCESS'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Auditing: Audit any CREATE statement

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Audit the use of any CREATE statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Auditing: Audit CREATE ROLE

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Audit the use of CREATE ROLE.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select ROWNUM from DBA_STMT_AUDIT_OPTS where AUDIT_OPTION = 'CREATE ROLE' and USER_NAME is null and PROXY_NAME is null and SUCCESS = 'BY ACCESS' and FAILURE = 'BY ACCESS'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Auditing: Audit CREATE USER

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Audit the use of CREATE USER.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select ROWNUM from DBA_STMT_AUDIT_OPTS where AUDIT_OPTION = 'CREATE USER' and USER_NAME is null and PROXY_NAME is null and SUCCESS = 'BY ACCESS' and FAILURE = 'BY ACCESS'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Auditing: Audit CREATE SESSION

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Audit the use of CREATE SESSION for successful or unsuccessful operations.

ecl:SQL-query.ecl:query: select ROWNUM from DBA_STMT_AUDIT_OPTS where AUDIT_OPTION = 'CREATE SESSION' and USER_NAME is null and PROXY_NAME is null and SUCCESS = 'BY ACCESS' and FAILURE = 'BY ACCESS'

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Auditing: Audit any DROP statement

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Audit the use of any DROP statement.
